qas.question: What script was developed with parts of Chinese characters?
What was the name of the cursive script that gave expression to spoken words?
Who is the author of The Pillow Book?
Who is the author of The Tale of Genji?
What was the name of the brightly colored paintings depicting court life?
What declined while the Fujiwara controled the imperial court?
Where did Japan borrow the writting style of hiragana from?
What writting style led to a decline in Japan's vernacular literature?
What was written by court women trained in Chinese?

plausible_answers.text: Japanese style paintings of court life and stories about temples and shrines

qas.question: What still influences Chinese art today?

context: Despite their usurpation of imperial authority, the Fujiwara presided over a period of <b5_0>cultural<b5_0/> and artistic flowering at the imperial court and among the aristocracy. There was great interest in graceful poetry and vernacular literature. Two types of phonetic Japanese script: <a0_0>katakana<a0_0/>, a simplified script that was developed by using parts of <b6_0>Chinese characters<b6_0/>, was abbreviated to <a1_0>hiragana<a1_0/>, a cursive syllabary with a distinct writing method that was uniquely Japanese. <b7_0>Hiragana<b7_0/> gave written expression to the spoken word and, with it, to the rise in <b8_0>Japan's famous vernacular literature<b8_0/>, much of it written by court women who had not been trained in Chinese as had their male counterparts. Three late tenth century and early eleventh century women presented their views of life and romance at the Heian court in Kagerō Nikki by "the mother of Fujiwara Michitsuna", The Pillow Book by <a2_0>Sei Shōnagon<a2_0/> and The Tale of Genji by <a3_0>Murasaki Shikibu<a3_0/>. Indigenous art also flourished under the Fujiwara after centuries of imitating Chinese forms. Vividly colored <a4_0>yamato-e<a4_0/>, <b9_0>Japanese style paintings of court life and stories about temples and shrines<b9_0/> became common in the mid- and late Heian periods, setting patterns for Japanese art to this day.
